Award.AwardTitle: Combinatorics, Algebra, and Topology of Stanley-Reisner Rings
Award.AbstractNarration:
Algebraic and geometric combinatorics, and, in particular, the study of discrete objects that approximate high-dimensional shapes, is a rapidly developing field that has close connections to optimization, computer science, engineering, statistics, and mathematical biology. For instance, in engineering and computer science, e.g., robotics, one often needs to describe a space of "allowed motions." This space can usually be approximated by a collection of points, segments, triangles, pyramids, and higher dimensional analogs of pyramids nicely glued together -- an object known as a simplicial complex. A simplicial complex, in turn, can be encoded in a certain algebraic structure that involves polynomials. Study of this algebraic structure led to several spectacular developments in the field. This research project aims to deepen understanding of various aspects of simplicial complexes and the corresponding algebraic structures.

The project aims to deepen our understanding of algebraic, combinatorial, and topological invariants of simplicial complexes through the study of their face numbers and Stanley-Reisner rings. Specifically, research on this project will attack fundamental questions related to (1) tracing various topological invariants (beyond the usual simplicial homology) in the Stanley-Reisner rings, (2) extending results on face numbers and Stanley-Reisner rings of triangulations of manifolds to the setting of normal pseudomanifolds, and (3) studying face numbers of simplicial complexes with an additional structure such as balancedness or symmetry. Thus, this project seeks to vastly improve our understanding of Stanley-Reisner rings (and modules) of complexes, especially when they are not Cohen-Macaulay or even not Buchsbaum. Consequently, it is expected that results of the project will impact not only algebraic and geometric combinatorics, but also commutative algebra, discrete geometry, and potentially even algebraic topology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal was aimed at attacking several long-standing problems and conjectures in the theory of face numbers of various classes of simplicial complexes and polytopes. Polytopes are high-dimensional generalization of polygons (e.g., triangles, squares, etc.) and objects like pyramids, cubes, and octahedra.  A simplicial complex is constructed from points, line segments, triangles, pyramids, and higher-dimensional analogs of pyramids (called simplices) by gluing these objects so that every two of them are either disjoint or intersect along their common face. Examples of simplicial complexes include graphs (these are one-dimensional simplicial complexes), triangulations of spheres (among them the boundary complexes of simplicial polytopes), as well as triangulations of much more general spaces.  Simplicial complexes and polytopes are among the central objects in the field of geometric combinatorics --- a rapidly developing field that has close connections to optimization, computer science, engineering, statistics, and even mathematical biology. Below we outline some of the main outcomes of the proposal.

In a joint project with Robert Amzi Jeffs, the PI studied simplicial complexes arising from a collection of convex sets. The research on such complexes has a rich and fascinating history starting with the Radon and Helly theorems. Additional motivation for investigating such complexes comes from the theory of convex neural codes ? a much younger subject that takes its origins in neurobiology. One of the fundamental open problems in the study of neural codes is which neural codes are convex, and one of the approaches to attack this question is via local obstructions. Jeffs and the PI established several new local obstructions strengthening prior results by Chen, Frick, and Shiu.

The upper bound theorem for polytopes (and triangulations of more general spaces) provides tight upper bounds on the number of j-dimensional faces in terms of the number of vertices and the dimension of the space. The motivation for this type of bounds partly comes from optimization. A related notion is that of neighborliness: a simplicial complex is k-neighborly if every set of k of its vertices forms the vertex set of a face. For example, a polytope is 2-neighborly if every two of its vertices are connected by an edge. While in dimension three, the only such polytope is a pyramid, in higher dimensions many such polytopes exist. In a joint work with Hailun Zheng, the PI constructed a very large family of highly neighborly triangulations of spheres of dimension d-1 with n vertices (for all d>4 and large n). For instance, for d=2021, the construction provides on the order of 2^(n^(1010)) neighborly triangulations. The previous record construction by Padrol only gave on the order of 2^(n log n) such triangulations.

A polytope is centrally symmetric if it is symmetric about the origin. Examples include regular polygons with an even number of sides. One can mimic this definition to define the notion of central symmetry for simplicial complexes. One can also appropriately adapt the notion of neighborliness for centrally symmetric complexes. In another joint work with Zheng, the PI constructed for all d>3 and arbitrarily large even n, a centrally symmetric triangulation of a sphere of dimension d-1 with n vertices that is highly centrally-symmetric-neighborly. That such objects might exist was anticipated since early seventies. The existence of such complexes combined with the previous results by Adin and Stanley completely resolved the upper bound problem for centrally symmetric triangulations of spheres.

 

 Broader impacts:  the PI is supervising graduate students, serves on the editorial boards of the Proceedings of the American Math Society, SIAM Journal on Discrete Mathematics, and Algebraic Combinatorics. She co-organizes various international conferences and workshops. She also co-organizers the Combinatorics seminar at the University of Washington.

 This grant supported the PI?s and her graduate students? talks at conferences and workshops as well as several research stays. It provided Research Assistantships for the PI's graduate students allowing them to focus on research. It also allowed the PI to bring visitors to the University of Washington, which in turn allowed the PI and her graduate students to start new collaborations.
